districts.title: Rotaract Clubs in Bulacan, Nueva Ecija, Nueva Vizcaya, Isabela, Cagayan, Ifugao, Quirino, Kalinga-Apayao, Batanes, and Baler.
districts.description:
Rotaract District 3770, a vital segment of Rotary International, serves the eastern and northern regions of Luzon in the Philippines. This district encompasses provinces such as Bulacan, Nueva Ecija, Nueva Vizcaya, Isabela, Cagayan, Ifugao, Quirino, Kalinga-Apayao, Batanes, and Baler. Originally part of District 3800, which included Rotary clubs north of the Pasig River, District 3770 was officially established during the 1987-88 Rotary year when District 3800 was divided into three separate districts. Since its inception, Rotaract District 3770 has been dedicated to fostering leadership, professional development, and community service among young adults. The district comprises numerous Rotaract clubs, each actively engaging in projects that address the unique needs of their communities. These clubs operate under the guidance and support of their sponsoring Rotary clubs, working collaboratively to implement initiatives that promote positive change.

In the current Rotary year, 2024-2025, the district is under the leadership of District Rotaract Representative (DRR) Ralph Bernardo. DRR Bernardo has articulated a clear vision aimed at enhancing the district’s impact and reach. His strategic goals for the year focus on
strengthening membership engagement, enhancing leadership development, expanding community service initiatives, promoting public image and awareness, and fostering partnerships and collaborations. He emphasizes the importance of active participation among members and aims to increase membership retention by fostering a sense of belonging and purpose within the clubs. Recognizing the potential of Rotaractors as future leaders, he is committed to providing comprehensive training programs designed to equip members with essential skills and knowledge for leadership roles within and beyond the organization. Under DRR Bernardo’s guidance, the district also plans to broaden the scope of its service projects by identifying and addressing pressing community issues through sustainable and impactful initiatives. To attract new members and garner support for various projects,he has launched efforts to enhance the public image of Rotaract District 3770. This involves leveraging social media platforms and other communication channels to highlight the district’s activities and achievements. Additionally, building strong relationships with external organizations, local governments, and other Rotary and Rotaract clubs is a priority. These partnerships aim to amplify the district’s efforts and resources, leading to more effective service delivery. 

A testament to the district’s commitment to these goals was the successful Mid-Year Review held recently, which featured the Mid-Year Awards recognizing the outstanding efforts of various clubs and individuals. During this event, DRR Bernardo also delivered the State of the District Address, highlighting achievements and outlining future goals. Through these concerted efforts, Rotaract District 3770 continues to empower young leaders, foster community development, and uphold the values of Rotary International. The district remains steadfast in its mission to create positive and lasting change within its communities, guided by the vision and leadership of DRR Ralph Bernardo.

districts.title: Rotaract Clubs from 11 provinces in the Northwestern region of Luzon, Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, Abra, La Union, Benguet, Pangasinan, Tarlac, Zambales, Pampanga, and Bataan
districts.description:
Rotary International District 3790 is made up of 473 rotaractors from 55 active Rotaract clubs, 2,753 active Rotarians, and 219 honorary members. 

Clubs from 11 provinces in the Northwestern region of Luzon, Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, Abra, La Union, Benguet, Pangasinan, Tarlac, Zambales, Pampanga, and Bataan make up our cherished District. RID 3790 is sometimes referred to as the "hospitable district" since everyone there extends a warm welcome to visitors and Rotaract family members. Visitors are also welcomed by the stunning and unique attractions of the various tourist destinations in our district. The neighborhood is tucked away in the embrace of nature, providing the ideal fusion of stunning scenery, a wealth of cultural history, and a kind, welcoming atmosphere. Whether you are an experienced tourist or a first-timer, this enchanted location guarantees a trip full of life-long experiences where breathtaking panoramic vistas and lush flora collide. The profound tranquility of the various regions combined with the environment's vivid hues make the ideal setting for a tranquil getaway. Our district is a true nature lover's paradise, whether you decide to explore its beautiful paths or just take in the serene surroundings.

With its distinct fusion of historical charm, natural beauty, and genuine warmth, DISTRICT 3790 is more than just a place to visit; it's an experience that should be treasured. Come discover the joys of our unique location, where each moment is like being held in a loving hug.

districts.title: Rotaract Clubs in Malabon, Navotas, Caloocan, Valenzuela, Marikina, Pasig, San Juan, Mandaluyong, and the Province of Rizal.
districts.description:
Rotaract Clubs of RID 3800, also known for its namesake as The Resilient District, is in Metropolitan Manila, Philippines. We are divided into 8 zones, covering the cities of Malabon, Navotas, Caloocan, Valenzuela, Marikina, Pasig, San Juan, Mandaluyong, and the Province of Rizal. The district currently has 82 clubs and 929 rotaractors. The district has already hosted 2 Pilipinas MDIO events such as Pilipinas Rotaract Convention 2018 and District Rotaract Representatives-Elect Training and Seminar 2022.

districts.title: Rotaract Clubs in Manila, Pasay, Cavite and Occidental Mindoro
districts.description:
Rotaract, one of Rotary International's most dynamic service programs, boasts a global reach with over 7,000 clubs in 163 countries. In the Philippines, the Rotaract journey began in 1972 with the establishment of the Rotaract Club of Adamson University, sponsored by the Rotary Club of Manila—the first Rotary club in Asia. This paved the way for the creation of many more Rotaract clubs across the country.

Initially part of District 380, which encompassed all clubs in Luzon, significant re-districting shaped the regions:

- 1977-1978: District 380 was divided, creating District 3820. This included Southern Metro Manila, Southern Tagalog, Bicol Region, Mindoro, Palawan, and Marinduque.
- 1985-1986: District 3820 was further split, forming District 3810, covering Manila (south of Pasig River), Cavite, Palawan, and Mindoro.
- 1999-2000: District 3810 was restructured, birthing District 3830, which now oversees Makati, Las Piñas, Parañaque, Taguig, Pateros, Palawan, and Oriental Mindoro. District 3810 retained Manila, Pasay, Cavite, and Occidental Mindoro.

Despite these changes, Rotaract clubs in District 3810 thrived, excelling in service and leadership:

- Service Excellence: Clubs are celebrated for impactful projects like "Gift of Learning" by the Rotaract Club of Manila, recognized as the Asia-Pacific Regional Winner.
- Leadership in Action: Rotaractors in the district have actively contributed to regional and international initiatives, including the Asia Pacific Regional Rotaract Conference (2006-2007) hosted under PDRR Rhosenie Villanueva.
- Global Participation: Members have engaged in programs like the Rotary Foundation’s Group Study Exchange, showcasing the district's commitment to global collaboration.

Today, District 3810 stands as a beacon of innovation, collaboration, and service, fostering leaders and initiatives that inspire change across the Asia-Pacific and beyond.

districts.title: Rotaract Clubs in the provinces of Laguna, Batangas, Quezon, Marinduque, Oriental Mindoro, Camarines Norte, Camarines Sur, Albay, Sorsogon, Catanduanes, and Masbate.
districts.description:
Rotaract District 3820, widely recognized as the “Fellowship Capital of the Philippine Rotaract,” is one of the largest and most dynamic Rotaract districts in the country. It is part of Rotary International District 3820, which comprises 149 Rotary clubs and 4,873 dedicated Rotarians committed to service and leadership.

The district has a strong legacy of hosting major Rotaract events, fostering fellowship, and strengthening professional and humanitarian connections. Among its notable accomplishments, District 3820 has successfully hosted the Asia Pacific Regional Rotaract Conference (APRRC Pilipinas), ProCon 2014 and 2019, RYLA Pilipinas, APRRC 2021, the International Rotaract Summit, the Rotaract Friendship Exchange Program, and the Area Tour. These events have significantly contributed to the development of Rotaractors, enhancing their leadership skills and expanding their network across the region and beyond.

Comprising 86 active Rotaract clubs with a membership of 1,117 Rotaractors, District 3820 is one of the largest Rotaract districts in the Philippines in terms of club numbers. It covers a vast geographical area, including the provinces of Laguna, Batangas, Quezon, Marinduque, Oriental Mindoro, Camarines Norte, Camarines Sur, Albay, Sorsogon, Catanduanes, and Masbate. This diverse coverage allows Rotaractors from various cultural and economic backgrounds to collaborate and drive impactful service projects in their respective communities.

The district is home to numerous historical and cultural heritage sites, as well as renowned tourist destinations. Visitors to the district will not only experience the warmth and hospitality of its people but also witness the rich history and natural beauty that make it a unique and vibrant region. The Rotarians and Rotaractors of District 3820 warmly welcome guests, ensuring an unforgettable stay filled with meaningful engagements and inspiring exchanges.

Rotaract District 3820 is composed of students, young professionals, and entrepreneurs who share a common goal of fostering service, leadership, and professional growth. The strong relationship between Rotaract and its sponsoring Rotary clubs is a testament to the spirit of "One Rotary Family." Through joint projects and collaborative initiatives, the district continues to uphold the core values of Rotary International, emphasizing service above self, leadership development, and community impact.

With its commitment to excellence, service, and fellowship, Rotaract District 3820 remains a beacon of youth empowerment and humanitarian service, making a lasting difference in the communities it serves.

districts.title: Rotaract Clubs in Las Pinas, Makati, Muntinlupa, Paranaque, Pateros, Taguig, and the Province of Palawan.
districts.description:
Striking a balance between modernization and tradition, advancement and preservation. District 3830 is known for being the home of the robust financial center, nostalgic heritage and delightful wonders of nature.

This administrative territory comprises of Las Pinas, Makati, Muntinlupa, Paranaque, Pateros, Taguig, and the Province of Palawan. The district envisions a network of united Rotaract Clubs, driving sustainable service projects and fostering Rotaractors who embody commitment, professionalism, and a shared dedication to service. Through unity, passion, and unwavering commitment, the district aims to create transformative change in the lives of communities it serves, while continually upholding its motto. Distrito Trentay Otso Trenta, Sama-Sama, Nagkakaisa

districts.title: Rotaract Clubs in Panay Island (Aklan, Antique, Capiz, Iloilo, Guimaras), Negros Occidental, Zamboanga Peninsula, and the provinces of Basilan, Misamis Occidental, Sulu, and Tawi-Tawi.
districts.description:
District 3850 is home of young, vibrant, and active Rotaractors and Interactors. As the district where the first Rotaract Club was chartered, District 3850 continues to imbibe the organization’s motto *“Fellowship Through Service”* and commits themselves to innovative ways of learning, giving, and educating the community towards progress.

We are the district divided by seas – Panay-Negros-Western Mindanao. Despite our differences, Rotary International District 3850 remains strong and intact in making its presence felt in various local, regional, national, and even international noble activities. Our respective cultures, traditions, ways of life, and even religions did not hamper us to think and ‘walk the talk’ to promote a common goal and harmonious bond.

To give you a little background of our district, it was during April 27, 1933 where the Rotary Club of Iloilo was Chartered, the third Rotary Club established in the Philippines.

On September 20, 1968, the birth of the First Charted Rotaract Club in the Philippines – Rotaract Club of West Negros College happened.

1984 – The redistricting of District 385 was approved after reaching 86 Clubs, with District 385 composed of Western Visayas and Western Mindanao. And when 1991 came, District 385 became District 3850.

districts.title: Rotaract Club in Cebu, Negros Oriental, Bohol, Siquijor, Agusan del Norte, Agusan del Sur, Surigao del Norte, Surigao del Sur, Samar, Leyte, Davao del Norte, Davao del Sur, Davao Oriental, South Cotabato, and General Santos.
districts.description:
Rotary International District 3860 is hailed as the most festive and culturally rich district in the Philippines. Encompassing Regions 7, 8, 11, 12, and 13, it spans a diverse and dynamic territory, including Cebu, Negros Oriental, Bohol, Siquijor, Agusan del Norte, Agusan del Sur, Surigao del Norte, Surigao del Sur, Samar, Leyte, Davao del Norte, Davao del Sur, Davao Oriental, South Cotabato, and General Santos.

Beyond its rich history and colorful traditions, District 3860 thrives as a beacon of service, leadership, and community impact. From the electrifying Sinulog Festival in Cebu to the vibrant Kadayawan Festival in Davao, the district embraces its multicultural heritage while channeling this spirit into meaningful humanitarian efforts.

At the heart of its service movement is Rotaract, a thriving force of young leaders and changemakers who work alongside Rotarians to drive impactful initiatives. Rotaract Clubs across the district lead diverse programs from medical missions and livelihood training to environmental sustainability and youth development strengthening Rotary’s commitment to Service Above Self.

The district’s Rotaractors play a crucial role in shaping the future of Rotary, fostering leadership through initiatives such through club development programs and multi-district collaborations. With a growing network of passionate volunteers, Rotaract in District 3860 continues to bridge gaps, empower communities, and create lasting change.

Together, Rotarians and Rotaractors in District 3860 exemplify the perfect blend of culture and service, proving that beyond the festivities lies a deeper purpose, a shared mission to uplift lives and transform communities.

featuredEvents.title: 14TH PILIPINAS ROTARACT CONVENTION
featuredEvents.description:
PROCON 2026: WE BEAT WITH YOU!

The Pilipinas Rotaract Convention (PROCON) 2026 is the biggest annual gathering of Rotaractors from all 10 districts across the Philippines. Happening on February 20–22, 2026, this year’s convention heads to the vibrant City of Love — Iloilo City!

With the theme "WE BEAT WITH YOU," PROCON 2026 celebrates the heart and rhythm of service, leadership, and unity. Inspired by the spirit of Iloilo, the event highlights "From Festive Streets to Flavor Feasts," promising a colorful fusion of learning, culture, and fellowship. Get ready to experience dynamic sessions, lively festivities, and a taste of Iloilo’s rich traditions as we come together to beat as one.

procon.title: 14th Pilipinas Rotaract Convention
procon.description:
PROCON 2026: WE BEAT WITH YOU! 

February 20-22, 2026
ILOILO CITY, PHILIPPINES | HOSTED BY ROTARY INTERNATIONAL DISTRICT 3850

procon.title: 10th Pilipinas Rotaract Convention
procon.description:
City of Majestic Waterfalls, Iligan City | Hosted by Rotary International District 3870

The PROCON 2022, being the first PROCON in Mindanao and the first to be hosted face-to-face in a pandemic-stricken Philippines, was definitely a half-week to remember. Despite all the restrictions, the delegates got to enjoy the city, the company of their fellow Rotaractors and the true spirit of Rotaract, which is “Fellowship Through Service”. The annual event is a perfect venue to embrace the diversity of the Pilipinas Rotaract, while celebrating oneness of goals, service and achievements. This is definitely a great way to celebrate the Rotary year!

rotaractStatisticsCards.title: Rotaractors Around the World as of April 2025
rotaractStatisticsCards.description: Rotaract has become a global movement with over 133,885 members in more than 9,397 clubs across 180 countries. Rotaract members are making significant impacts in their communities through service projects, leadership development, and international cooperation initiatives.

rotaractStatisticsCards.title: Rotaract Clubs in the Philippines as of April 2025
rotaractStatisticsCards.description: The Philippines is home to 608 Rotaract clubs distributed across 10 districts. The strong Rotaract presence in the country reflects the commitment of young Filipino professionals and students to service, leadership, and community development through the Rotary network.

rotaractStatisticsCards.title: Rotaract Members in the Philippines as of April 2025
rotaractStatisticsCards.description: With 8,094 active members, Philippine Rotaract represents one of the largest and most active Rotaract communities globally. These young leaders are engaged in numerous service projects, professional development initiatives, and cross-district collaborations through the MDIO framework.

rotaractStatisticsCharts.title: PH Rotaract Contributions (Per district in USD)

leadershipChair.name: PDRR John Philip S. Chan
leadershipChair.title: Chairperson, Pilipinas Rotaract Multi-District Information Organization
leadershipChair.description: Leading with dedication and innovation, our Chair works tirelessly to strengthen Rotaract's presence and impact across the Philippines, fostering collaboration between districts and empowering the next generation of leaders.
leadershipChair.club: Rotaract Club of Taguig, Rotary International District 3830

actions.title: Chairperson, Pilipinas Rotaract Multi-District Information Organization (MDIO) Rotary Year 2025–2026
actions.description:
PDRR John Philip Chan has already become a name synonymous with servant leadership, purpose-driven impact, and unwavering dedication to the ideals of Rotaract. With a heart for public service and a mind sharpened by experience, John stands today as the Chairperson of the Pilipinas Rotaract Multi-District Information Organization—leading the nation’s premier platform for collaboration and innovation among Rotaract clubs in the Philippines.

A proud graduate of Lyceum of the Philippines University – Manila with a degree in Foreign Service, Major in Diplomacy, John continues to pursue excellence through graduate studies in Public Management at the University of the Philippines – Open University. His academic journey is marked not only by scholarly pursuits but by a commitment to make governance work for the people.

His leadership extends far beyond the classroom. John has served at the heart of Philippine policymaking—as Deputy Party List Manager under Congresswoman Marissa “Del Mar” Magsino and as a Political Affairs Officer under the distinguished Senator Richard J. Gordon. Recognized early on for his leadership potential, he was awarded the Gerry Roxas Leadership Award—a reflection of the impact he continues to make.

But it is in Rotaract where John’s passion truly found its purpose.

From his beginnings as President of the Rotaract Club of South Signal Village, he quickly rose as a transformational leader. Under his guidance, the club garnered multiple awards across all avenues of service, including gold, silver, and bronze distinctions for its impactful programs. His excellence in leadership earned him the rare honor of being appointed District Secretary of Rotaract District 3830 for two consecutive terms—proof of his consistency, credibility, and character.

In 2017, John made history. Not only was he elected as President of the LPU English Club—the university’s largest student organization—but he also became the first elected District Rotaract Representative-Nominee and, later, the youngest District Rotaract Representative of RI District 3830. At just 22, he led 71 clubs across Metro Manila and Palawan, setting a new standard for youth-led governance in Rotary.

After his trailblazing term, he co-founded the Rotaract Club of Taguig—the first in his district and one of only two in the country without a sponsoring Rotary club. This bold and barrier-breaking move united seasoned leaders from four different clubs, proving that collaboration—not structure—creates impact.

John’s journey in Pilipinas Rotaract MDIO is equally inspiring. From a Learning and Development Associate to Deputy Chief for Policy and Process Improvement, to a two-term Treasurer—and now, Chairperson—he has embodied the MDIO’s mission to connect, empower, and elevate Filipino Rotaractors. Under his leadership, the MDIO continues to champion excellence, innovation, and unity across all districts nationwide.

More than his titles, it is John’s humility, vision, and authenticity that define him. He reminds us that age is not a limitation, that service is not about status, and that leadership is not about being in front—but being for others.

John Philip Chan is not just a leader of today—he is a catalyst for tomorrow, and a living example of what’s possible when passion meets purpose in the spirit of “Service Above Self.”

introduction.title: Supporting The Rotary Foundation's Global Impact
introduction.content: The Rotary Foundation transforms your gifts into service projects that change lives both close to home and around the world. Since 1917, the Foundation has spent more than $4 billion on life-changing, sustainable projects that help people in need with access to safe water, medical care, literacy, education, and other critical needs. By giving to the Foundation, you become an essential part of these ongoing efforts to create lasting positive change in communities everywhere.

funds.title: Annual Fund
funds.description: The Annual Fund is the primary source of funding for Foundation activities. Your contributions to the Annual Fund help Rotary clubs take action to create positive change in communities at home and around the world. Through grants and projects, Rotary members combat diseases like polio and malaria, provide clean water, improve economic opportunities, and promote peace.

funds.title: PolioPlus Fund
funds.description: Rotary has been working to eradicate polio for more than 35 years. Our goal of ridding the world of this disease is closer than ever. When you contribute to the PolioPlus Fund, you're supporting Rotary's top priority - ensuring that polio is eradicated and that it never returns. Your donation helps deliver vaccinations, transportation, and educational materials.

funds.title: Endowment Fund
funds.description: The Endowment Fund ensures the long-term financial stability of the Foundation and provides essential support for Rotary's programs. Contributions to the Endowment Fund are invested in perpetuity, with a portion of the fund's earnings spent on Foundation programs each year. This provides a steady and reliable source of income to meet the world's greatest needs.

funds.title: Disaster Response Fund
funds.description: The Rotary Disaster Response Fund provides a ready mechanism for Rotary districts to respond quickly to local disasters. Districts in affected areas may receive disaster response grants to provide basic items such as water, food, medicine, and clothing. Your support enables our communities to recover more quickly after devastating natural disasters.
